cleaned_text: President of the European Commission A safe and effective malaria vaccine has long been an elusive target. But this could change now. This week we shared that we are joining forces towards a breakthrough in malaria vaccine development: The [European Commission](https://be.linkedin.com/company/european-commission?trk=public_post-text) and the [European Investment Bank (EIB)](https://lu.linkedin.com/company/european-investment-bank?trk=public_post-text) are throwing their weight behind the global effort to develop mRNA vaccines against malaria. In the past months, the world has seen the power of the mRNA technology, pioneered by [BioNTech SE](https://de.linkedin.com/company/biontech-se?trk=public_post-text) and others. We are witnessing the start of a revolution in medical science: mRNA technology has been a game-changer in the fight against [#COVID19](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Ffeed%2Fhashtag%2Fcovid19&trk=public_post-text). It can be a game-changer in the fight against other diseases too, including malaria. Eradicating malaria is a realistic goal. And now we know that it can be achieved already in this generation. The European Commission and the European Investment Bank will join the global effort through our Infectious Diseases Finance Facility. And we will work together with BioNTech and with some of the main global health actors. This initiative is part of a broader engagement by the [#EuropeanUnion](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Ffeed%2Fhashtag%2Feuropeanunion&trk=public_post-text) for health in [#Africa](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Ffeed%2Fhashtag%2Fafrica&trk=public_post-text) and in the developing world. Africa today imports 99% of its vaccines. Our African partners want to end this dependency. And we want to help them achieve this goal.
